question: Homer, if you're going to stay at St. Cloud's, I expect you to be of use. But, in failing to withhold love, had I created a true and everlasting orphan? I had been too successful with Homer Wells. I had managed to make the orphanage his *home*. God forgive me. I have *made* an orphan by loving him too much. Homer Wells will belong to St. Cloud's, forever.
answer: Dr. Larch! Dr. Larch! We've got two new patients, one to deliver.

question: First pregnancy?
answer: Yes, for both.

question: I presume you'd prefer handling the delivery.
answer: All I said was, I don't want to perform abortions. I have no argument with *you* performing them.

question: You know *how* to help these women-- how can you not feel *obligated* to help them when they can't get help anywhere else?
answer: One

question: What *else* could I have showed you, Homer? The only thing I can teach you is what I know! In every life, you've got to be of use. Have you ever had ether, Dorothy?
answer: No one's touched your appendix.

question: It won't make you sick this time, Dorothy--not the way I do it, just a drop at a time. One day, Dorothy, if you have any money, a donation to the orphanage would be very much appreciated.
answer: Only if you can afford it.

question: Would you mind having a look at Dorothy?
answer: There was no visible wound?

question: No. The fetus was dead. Her uterus was virtually *disintegrating*--my stitches pulled right through the tissue!
answer: It looks like scurvy.

question: It's obviously an aborticide.
answer: Obviously. Christ, it's oil of tansy!

question: I don't know it.
answer: If you take enough of it, your intestines lose their ability to absorb Vitamin C.

question: In other words, scurvy.
answer: Good boy. Good job. And you call yourself "not a doctor"! Keep an eye on her--she's in trouble. Take care of that, will you?

question: I'll help you. He *sniffs* that ether! I've seen him do it!
answer: It's because he's too tired to sleep. He has to.

question: He *smells* like he could put you to sleep!
answer: He's a doctor, Buster--doctors smell like ether.

question: *You're* a doctor, Homer--you don't smell like ether.
answer: I'm *not* a doctor. I haven't been to medical school--I haven't even been to high school!

question: But you've studied with the old man for *years*!
answer: I'm *not* a doctor!

question: Fuzzy is not uncommon. I tell you, there's something about the premature babies of alcoholic mothers. They seem susceptible to every damn thing that comes along.
answer: I haven't read that.

question: I haven't, either. But you *will*. The morons who write the books should do a little research *here*.
answer: But isn't Fuzzy just... well, underdeveloped?

question: When *doesn't* he have bronchitis? I wouldn't call his bronchial infections "underdeveloped." Would you?
answer: What is it, Mary Agnes?

question: What is it, Mary Agnes?
answer: Look!

question: Did you bite it?
answer: I don't remember.

question: It looks like you bit it--it'll be all right.
answer: Maybe I was kissing someone and he bit me.

question: No, you did it yourself. Maybe in your sleep.
answer: I must have been *dreaming* of kissing someone.

question: Life is waiting. Where's the name sheet?
answer: Nobody's named this one yet.

question: It's my turn! Henceforth you shall be... Little Dorrit!
answer: He doesn't like it. He's a boy, That's why.

question: Can't a boy be a Dorrit?
answer: I don't think so.

question: You do it then.
answer: Henceforth you shall be... Little Wilbur.

question: I'm not crazy about the "Little..."
answer: Okay, he's just a Wilbur then.

question: If people want to adopt one of us, they should have to take the oldest first.
answer: Please, Mary Agnes! This is Hazel's special day--don't make her feel sad.

question: Hazel's practically the youngest of us. She should be the *last* to leave! They take the babies so they won't ever have to tell them that they were orphans! If you cry, Hazel, they'll just send you back.
answer: Mary Agnes, that's not true!

question: That's what they did to me!
answer: You *wanted* to come back--that's why you cried. You can cry if you feel like it, Hazel. You cry as much as you want.

question: Hi, Curly. You going somewhere?
answer: I thought they might take me.

question: They wanted a girl.
answer: Nobody ever wants me!

question: You're one of the best, Curly--we couldn't let just anyone take you.
answer: Dr. Larch wouldn't let just anyone take *any* of us!

question: That's true.
answer: Nobody's asked for me, have they?

question: Nobody special enough, Curly.
answer: You mean somebody asked?

question: I was dreaming about you. How beautiful you were!
answer: You weren't dreaming about me.

question: I was!
answer: Then I wasn't beautiful.

question: You were! You *are*! It was fantastic.
answer: It was just the ether, Wilbur...

question: Are you okay? Can I get you anything? Okay.
answer: Do you ever think about leaving this place to go find them? I mean your parents.

question: I know who you mean. I think about leaving here, but not to find *them*.
answer: Why not?

question: Whoever they were, they didn't *do* any of the things parents are supposed to do. Dr. Larch did those things, and Nurse Edna, and Nurse Angela.
answer: Yeah. But sometimes I wish I could meet mine, anyway.

question: What for, Buster? What would you do if you met them?
answer: Uh... I'd like to show them that I can cook, a little.

question: You cook very well!
answer: And that I can drive a truck!

question: Better than I can!
answer: Sometimes I want to meet them so I can kill them. Just sometimes. Homer, you know I would never kill anyone--you know I wouldn't.

question: I know.
answer: I think Mary Agnes could kill someone.

question: I doubt it. She's just an... ...emotional girl.
answer: What's she so emotional about?

question: Homer, would you get this one?
answer: She's a patient, right? She should see a doctor.

question: Homer, you are a skilled and gifted surgeon. You have near-prefect obstetrical and gynecological procedure.
answer: I just mean I'd rather fix the movie. Tonight.

question: Is *your* father dead?
answer: Cirrhosis--it's a disease of the liver.

question: *Liver* killed him?
answer: *Alcohol* killed him--he drank himself to death.

question: But did you know him?
answer: Barely. It hardly mattered that I knew him.

question: Did you know your mother better?
answer: She's dead now, too. She was a nanny.

question: What's a nanny do?
answer: She looks after other people's children.

question: Did you grow up around here?
answer: No. She was an immigrant.

question: What's an immigrant?
answer: Someone not from Maine.

question: How old are you, dear? Thirteen? Twelve? Are you twelve, dear? You have to tell me how long you've been pregnant. Three months? Are you *four* months pregnant?
answer: She's at least *five*.

question: Dear child, it won't hurt when I look. I'm just going to *look*. Tell me Did you go to someone else?
answer: Stuck *what* inside you?

question: She died of *secrecy*, she died of *ignorance*... If you expect people to be responsible for their children, you have to give them the right to decide whether or not to *have* children. Wouldn't you agree?
answer: How about expecting people to be responsible enough to control themselves to begin with?

question: How about this child? You expect *her* to be responsible?
answer: I didn't mean her. I'm talking about... adults. You know who I mean! What?!

question: It's just a marvel to me that you still have such high expectations of people.
answer: I'm happy I amuse you.

question: Try to look at it this way. What choice does Buster have? What are his options? Nobody will ever adopt him.
answer: Try to look at it *this* way. Buster and I are sitting right here beside you. We could have ended up in the incinerator!

question: Happy to be alive, under any circumstances--is that your point?
answer: Happy to be alive... I guess so.

question: I'm the best one.
answer: Here, blow...

question: I really *am* the best, I just have a cold.
answer: Blow! There, I bet that feels better.

question: What kind of plane are you flying?
answer: A B-24 Liberator.

question: Liberator...
answer: Have you enlisted?

question: They wouldn't take me. I'm Class IV-- I've got a heart defect.
answer: Really! Is it serious?

question: No, it's not serious. I'm just not supposed to get excited. You know-- no strain, no stress. I try to keep calm all the time.
answer: Oh, well. I don't imagine there's any strain or stress around *here*! How is she doing?

question: Homer, when is Halloween?
answer: Uh... it's the end of October.

question: Is that soon? Oh. It's the best time! How come we only get pumpkins once a year?
answer: Don't get too excited, Fuzzy.

question: Why can't we have pumpkins for Christmas, too? We don't get any good presents at Christmas, anyway.
answer: Has anyone offered you anything to eat?

question: Has anyone offered you anything to eat?
answer: Actually, someone did. I just didn't think I could eat anything.

question: I wonder if you might give me a ride.
answer: Sure! Be glad to! Uh... a ride where?

question: Where are you going?
answer: We're heading back to Cape Kenneth.

question: Doubtless you'll let me know what immensely worthwhile or at least *useful* thing it is that you find to do.
answer: I wasn't intending to leave here in order to be entirely useless--I expect I'll find some ways to be of use.

question: In other parts of the world, I suppose there are other ways.
answer: Of course.

question: Are you really so *stupid* that you imagine you're going to find a more gratifying life? What you're going to find is people like the poor people who get left here--only nobody takes care of them as well! And you won't be able to take care of them, either. There's no taking care of *anybody*-- not out there!
answer: You know I'm grateful for everything you've done for me...

question: I don't need your gratitude.
answer: I don't need this--I know all about my condition.

question: He'll need clothes... some money...
answer: Let him try to *make* some money! That's part of "seeing the world," isn't it?

question: Oh, just stop it! You knew this was going to happen. He's a young man.
answer: He's still a boy--out in the world, he's still a boy.

question: Just find him some clothes, Wilbur. He could use some clothes.
answer: I think these will fit you.

question: Actually, the Army has given me leave twice. First when my father died, and now I'm on leave to help my mother-- I'm just trying to get her ready for the harvest. She's no farmer. Apples were my dad's business. And with the war on, she's short on pickers.
answer: Wally thinks apples are boring.

question: I never said they were boring.
answer: You said, "Apples aren't exactly flying."

question: Well, they aren't.
answer: I think I'd probably like the apple business.

question: You're a little overqualified, aren't you?
answer: No, I'm not. I need a job.

question: Is your family in the apple business, too?
answer: No, but I work there--I like it. My dad's a lobsterman.

question: I've never seen a lobster.
answer: Really?

question: I couldn't have a baby with someone who's leaving me--I didn't know what else to do!
answer: I know.

question: He's going to be dropping bombs on Mandalay! They're going to be shooting at him!
answer: Where's Mandalay?

question: Burma!
answer: Oh...

question: I can't have a baby alone. I don't even know if he's coming back!
answer: I understand.

question: It should taper off tomorrow, but it can come back again. You have cramps? They'll ease up, almost entirely. As long as the bleeding isn't heavy, it's normal.
answer: Catch! Give it here! What was *that*?! Come over here! It's called the Burma run. It's about a seven-hour round-trip flight between India and China.

question: "Burma run" because you fly over Burma...
answer: *And* over the Himalayas. That's called flying over the hump.

question: At what altitude?
answer: I've got thirty-five minutes to climb to fifteen thousand feet--that's the first mountain pass.

question: What lousy luck--I mean your orders... to draw an assignment like that!
answer: Actually, I volunteered.

question: It's the flying, right? You love to fly, don't you?
answer: I love the bombing, too. But there's also the Himalayas--they have the most wicked air currents in the world. I wouldn't miss flying there for anything. Uh, look... if you're serious about wanting a job, picking apples isn't that boring.

question: What's that?
answer: It's just my heart.

question: What you got a picture of your heart for?
answer: There's a little something wrong with it. Just this part here--the right ventricle. It's slightly enlarged.

question: So what?
answer: Yes, so what. It's nothing serious, really. Just a small defect.

question: You getting along okay? You girls make it hard for a guy to go off to war. But I'll leave my best man here to pinch-hit for me. Uh... I'm shipping out sooner than I thought. I just wanted to be sure you were settled in--and happy enough, considering... Are you bored stiff? Or can you stick it out for a bit?
answer: Uh... actually, picking apples is as much excitement as I want for a while. I'm grateful for the job.

question: You're the one who's helping *me*, Homer. You're going to give my mom a little peace of mind while I'm gone. Candy, too.
answer: Well, sure... that's good, then. All I mean is, I'm lucky I met you.

question: One has to be more than "careful" of Mrs. Goodhall--she has sufficient Christian zeal to start her own country! I'd like to give her a little ether.
answer: So what are you going to do?

question: "Homer Wells, born Portland, Maine, March 2, 1915..."
answer: Homer was born *here*, in, what was it, 1922?

question: "...graduated Bowdoin College, 1935, and Harvard School of Medicine, 1939."
answer: This is *your* life story, Wilbur! You just changed the dates!

question: "An internship and two years of training at the Boston Lying-in, South End Branch. For his age, he was judged an accomplished gynecological obstetrical surgeon; he is also experienced in pediatric care..."
answer: You *invented* him! You've completely made his up!

question: You think so, Jack? Well... I wouldn't want to be in that Wally's shoes tonight.
answer: Daddy, I'd like to be in that Wally's shoes *every* night.

question: You lucky you in your work boots tonight, girl...
answer: What's lucky about that?

question: You know where that Wally is tonight, darlin'? He's up there in them angry stars. He's flyin' all around up there... with them Japs shooting at him. They all on board, Mrs. Worthin'ton.
answer: Thank you, Arthur. And how is our Homer working out?

question: Oh, he's a smart young man, most of the time--Wally was right about him.
answer: No rotten apples?

question: No, no--not this year. Well... maybe we got *one*, but it ain't Homer.
answer: Rose... dear girl, I'm sure I can find you some other clothes. You must have some things that would fit her.

question: So. Not bored yet?
answer: I'm *never* bored! It's all very... different for me... here. Uh... have you been *feeling* okay?

question: When I'm not thinking about Wally. I'm not good at being alone. Oh, goodness. You meant... yes, I'm fine. I... ...I don't suppose you've seen a lobster yet. You have to come to my dad's lobster pound and see one, then.
answer: Okay... I better go.

question: Everything that falls to the bottom.
answer: It's time somebody ate *them*.

question: I was lookin' for Wally's letter. I was gonna show it to Homer... They made him a captain already-- *Captain* Worthington!
answer: Daddy, it's a letter to *me*.

question: He mentions Homer, too, you know.
answer: Wally said to say, "Hello."

question: A movie *outside*?
answer: Yes. But it's closed all the time now, because of the blackout.

question: People watched the movies in their cars?
answer: When they watched at all. Do you like movies?

question: Yes! I've only seen one, though.
answer: You've seen only one movie? Which one?

question: "King Kong". It's really good.
answer: I haven't seen "King Kong" since I was a kid!

question: You don't find it depressing that Homer Wells is picking apples? Or that he can't be bothered to write us a proper letter? A dissertation on apples, we don't need!
answer: He probably doesn't make much money picking apples--he must have had to pay to send them, too.

question: I wouldn't worry, Edna, that he doesn't have money. If he gets hungry, he can pick his dinner!
answer: Wilbur, it's a *gift*! How can you be angry with Homer for sending us a *gift*?

question: But you looked as if you liked it.
answer: I *did* like it. All I said was, "It's not 'King Kong'." First she loved him, then she didn't, then no one else could have him...

question: She *did* love him! How many women have you known?
answer: And what did she die of, exactly?

question: She was torn apart! She died of a broken heart.
answer: Oh, sure! What's the *medical* explanation?

question: Well, she was in a weakened condition... I don't know! What about "King Kong"?! Is that medically possible?
answer: At least King Kong knew what he *wanted*.

question: He looks like a bleeding-heart missionary *moron* to me, but that's going to be the problem with any doctor interested in coming here!
answer: Do you know him?

question: *No*! I don't want to know him! He's doing *missionary* work--in *India*! I wrote him *weeks* ago, but he's either too holy or too busy to answer. Maybe he got killed in the war!
answer: I fail to see how someone courageous enough to make a commitment to a foreign mission is automatically to be dismissed--that part of the world requires precisely the kind of dedication that is needed here.

question: Does it *snow* in Bombay? One winter here and we'll be shipping him south, in a *coffin*!
answer: You can't think that a man who has *served* under such conditions as exist over there will be in the slightest daunted by a little *snow*-- have you no idea how harsh and primitive and full of *disease* that part of the world is?

question: Of *course* there's worms, Homer! And what is them worms, really? They just *protein*, them worms! They is *good* for you! That just ain't right, Jack--your cigarette's gonna end up in nine or ten gallons of this batch of cider! That ain't right.
answer: Them people drinkin' that cider, they don't know there's a cigarette in there!

question: It's not that hard to find it in there, Jack--it'll take you just a minute. You just gotta go fishin'.
answer: You mean *swimmin'*. I ain't goin' in that vat to fish out no cigarette!

question: I don't need no "almost" a doctor, Homer.
answer: We should drown that damn Jack in the vat!

question: Now, now, darlin'... Jack just needs to know what business he's in.
answer: Yeah, you really showed him, Daddy-- you just about cut your own hand off, and all you cut off *him* was his clothes!

question: You're a natural. You were born to drive a car like this.
answer: You think? Maybe I was. I love this place! The screen is enormous! Imagine King Kong up *there*! Have you seen a lot of movies here?

question: Yes... and no. When you come here, you don't really care about the movie.
answer: You don't care about the movie?

question: What are you so crazy about the movies for?
answer: It was my favorite night at the orphanage--movie night. We'd race into the dining hall. Of course everyone wanted to sit in front, so we'd be packed in so tight you could feel the kid next to you breathing.

question: At least you were never lonely.
answer: I didn't say that. Growing up in an orphanage, you're always lonely. You're just never alone. You're not alone in the bathroom, or... or in the shower... you're never alone in wanting the last piece of meatloaaf, or even in your own bed on a cold morning.

question: You don't miss it?
answer: I miss things. I miss... people. I miss reading to the boys.

question: But you had so much *responsibility*.
answer: I never *asked* for any responsibility.

question: Just a little privacy. Privacy is exactly the point of drive- in movies.
answer: Did you come here with Wally--to *not* watch movies?

question: Sometimes... movies mostly bore Wally.
answer: Ah-ha. So what is that--a radio?

question: The *speaker*. For the movie sound. Scrunch down like this.
answer: How could you not *care* about the movie?

question: You just cuddle. You come to hug... to kiss. You don't *come* here to watch the movie.
answer: That's what *I'd* come here for. I'd watch the movie.

question: Fuzzy? Fuzzy?
answer: What are you going to tell the little ones?

question: I'll tell them Fuzzy was adopted.
answer: Why would the little ones believe that *anyone* would adopt him?

question: They'll believe it because they want to believe it.
answer: Shouldn't we tell Homer?

question: Just tell me. Do you want me to go? Do you want me to stay?
answer: It will be okay.

question: *What* will be okay?
answer: We have to wait and see. I think that, for *everything* in life, you have to wait and see.

question: I used to hate it when Wally went back to college--even when it was just college! And this was when his father was still alive... I hated it even then. Naturally I hate this more. What I mean is... I would like it very much if you thought you could be happy here, Homer.
answer: Mrs. Worthington, I feel I'm very lucky to be here.

question: There's not a lot of work in the winter, and you'll have to tolerate Vernon--even Wally despises him, and Wally likes everyone.
answer: I think Wally will be fine, Mrs. Worthington--he seems indestructible to me.

question: I don't know. Just promise me one thing.
answer: Uh... sure.

question: Dear Dr. Larch, what I am learning here may not be as important as what I learned from you, but everything is new to me. Yesterday I learned how to poison mice. You use poison oats and poison corn. Field mice girdle an apple tree. Pine mice kill the roots. I *know* what you have to do--you have to play God. Well... killing mice is as close as I want to come to playing God.
answer: Do I interfere? When absolutely helpless women tell me that they simply *can't* have an abortion, that they simply *must* go through with having another--and yet another-- orphan... do I interfere? *Do* I? I do not. I do not even *recommend*. I just give them what they want

question: I am not a doctor.
answer: You know everything I know, plus what you've taught yourself--you're a better doctor then I am and you know it! They're going to replace me, Homer! The Board of Trustees is looking for my *replacement*!

question: I can't replace you! I'm sorry...
answer: Sorry? I'm not 'sorry'! Not for anything I've done. I'm not even sorry that I love you!

question: Do you think I'm having a good time? Do you think I'm just *teasing* you? Do you think I *know* whether I want you or Wally?
answer: So we should "wait and see." For how long?

question: I grew up with Wally. I began my adult life with him.
answer: Fine. That's all there is to it then.

question: No! That's not all there is to it! I love you, too--I *know* I do.
answer: Okay, okay--I know you do, too.

question: You okay, Rose?
answer: I guess you must like watchin' me be sick...

question: I don't like watching anyone be sick. How many months are you? You're not yet three months, are you?
answer: Not yet. What do you know about it?

question: I know more than I want to know about it. Who's the father?
answer: Don't trouble yourself about it, Homer--this ain't your business.

question: But you don't look very happy.
answer: *Happy*! What are you thinkin'? How am I supposed to take care of a baby! I can't have a baby.

question: Rose, please listen. Whatever you want to do, I can help you. What I mean is, if you don't want to... keep the baby, I know a place where you can go.
answer: You think Daddy's gonna let me go anywhere? I ain't going *nowhere*. Why don't you just go back to your pickin', Homer? I can take care of it myself!

question: Well, we have to help her! We have to do *something*. Don't we? Homer? Hi...
answer: Hi...

question: I've got some more clothes for you-- I just keep forgetting to bring them with me.
answer: I don't need no more clothes, thank you.

question: Rose, I know what's going on. Homer told me. I got pregnant, too--about a year ago. I've been through this.
answer: You ain't been through what I been through, Candy.

question: Yes, I *have*! Who's the father, Rose? You want to have the baby? I know where you can go. Homer and I can take you...
answer: I can't go nowhere.

question: Why? Is it the father? Does he know? You can trust me. Is it Jack? It's not Jack, is it? It's *Muddy*! Is it Muddy?
answer: No. It ain't Muddy. Muddy's just... It sure ain't Jack.

question: She won't go to St. Cloud's!
answer: Well, we can't force her. It's her decision.

question: You don't understand! It's her father...
answer: Mr. Rose *knows*?

question: He's the *father*! He's her baby's father!
answer: Wait... *wait*! Are you sure?

question: I didn't see where you was pickin' this mornin', Homer, but you musta worked up a big appetite. You look like you're serious about gettin' to your lunch today!
answer: Is it true? Are you sleeping with your own daughter?

question: I think you been stayin' up too late at night, Homer.
answer: You're actually having sex with your own little girl? Is that possible?

question: Ain't nobody havin' *sex* with my little girl, Homer--that's somethin' a father knows.
answer: You're lying. How can you... with your own daughter!

question: Homer, don't you know what business you in? You don't wanna go into no business with me, Homer--ain't that right?
answer: Go on, cut my clothes. I've got other clothes.

question: You a fine one to be talkin' about lies. Shame! These people took you in. That boy Wally's at *war*!
answer: But she's your *daughter*...

question: And I *love* her! There ain't nobody else gonna treat her as good as I do! I wouldn't do nothin' to hurt her, Homer--you must know that.
answer: She's *pregnant*. Do you know *that*?

question: Because the crew thought he'd gone down with the plane. They were hospitalized for almost a week in China before they were flown back to India. It wasn't until that they sorted through their gear...
answer: Who cares about their *gear*?

question: Three men jumped from the plane, but they had four compasses with them. One of the crew jumped with Captain Worthington's compass.
answer: He was in Burma for twenty days without a compass?

question: Good night, Daddy.
answer: Good night, Ray. Just tell me. I'll do whatever you want to do.

question: Nothing.
answer: Isn't that like waiting and seeing?

question: No. Nothing is nothing. I want Wally to come home. I'm afraid to see him, too.
answer: I know. Is *that* nothing.

question: No, don't--that's something. Nothing is nothing. Don't even look at me. I want... ...to do nothing.
answer: It's a tempting idea, I know... to do nothing.

question: Please don't move, don't go anywhere.
answer: *Go* anywhere? Of course not! That would be *doing* something, wouldn't it? We wouldn't want to *do* something. Let's just sit here all night!

question: If you're trying to be funny, Homer...
answer: I'm not trying to be anything--I'm just doing nothing! If I wait and see long enough, then--with any luck-- I won't *ever* have to make up my mind! Decisions can be painful, after all...

question: Stop it! Just cut it out!
answer: You got up! You *did* something! If you keep this up, you might be in danger of making a *decision*!

question: For God's sake, Homer, Wally's been shot down!
answer: I know, I'm sorry.

question: He's *paralyzed*!
answer: He's *alive*. He still loves you. So do I.

question: What do you want me to *do*?
answer: Nothing. You're not the one who has to do anything.

question: What's that? What's it called?
answer: One cervical stabilizer, two sets of dilators--Douglas points. One medium- sized curette, one small; one medium speculum, one large; two vulsellum forceps.

question: There ain't no *almost* about this stuff, Homer--ain't that right?
answer: Merthiolate, ether, vulval pads, gauze--lots of gauze.

question: When it comes to this, you is the real thing--is that what you sayin'?
answer: No *almost* about it--I'm a doctor. Get out of here, please.

question: I'm stayin', Homer.
answer: Okay. Then you can be of use.

question: Right.
answer: Please don't make me say it again.

question: No, that's not it--I just want to be sure I understand you. I *helped* you not to think about Wally. You were so upset--you couldn't stand worrying about him, about his being killed and not coming back-- but when you were with me, you could stop worrying... well, for a while, anyway. This is how I helped you, right?
answer: Please... that's enough. I *loved* you, too--you know I did.

question: "...did." Well, okay.
answer: Please don't...

question: And now that Wally's coming back, and because he'll certainly *need* you...
answer: You say that as though it's some awful thing! I never stopped loving Wally!

question: Do you think she'll be all right?
answer: She knows how to take care of herself.

question: This came for you a couple of days ago. Olive asked me to bring it. With everything happening, I guess she forgot.
answer: Sure. Thanks.

question: I know you don't think much of being needed, or of me for that matter...
answer: I'm sorry for what I said about Wally needing you. It was... unnecessary.

question: No, I'm the one who should be sorry. You have every right to be angry.
answer: No. You warned me. I didn't listen, but you warned me. You told me you weren't any good at being alone. You told Wally, too. Right? He's going to be fine, Wally's going to be fine. I know he is.

question: He ain't never been outta Maine!
answer: Ain't you sick of pine trees, Homer?

question: Let me tell you somethin' about Florida, Homer.
answer: The Sunshine State!
